trial_identification.studytitle: The effects of awake suggestion on propofol induced pain during intravenous induction of anaesthesia: a randomised controlled trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effects of awake suggestion on propofol induced pain during intravenous induction of anaesthesia: a randomised controlled trial

conditions.healthcondition: Pain on injection in patients undergo anaesthesia

interventions.interventions: Patients will be given the suggestion that it is a warm strong pressure sensation going up the arm (Intervention). This is said just prior to and during intravenous induction of anaesthesia with propofol.
interventions.comparator: Patients will be given standard information about propofol injection that it will sting (Control). This is said just prior to and during intravenous induction of anaesthesia with propofol.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Pain on injection as measured by observing the patient's response from the commencement of propofol administration to loss of consciousness by an independant observer unaware of the intervention. 0 response - no grimace or withdrawal; 1= minimal movement or slight grimace; 2= clear grimace and / or moderate movement; 3 = vocalising pain
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At the commencement of propofol administration to loss of consciousness

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Satisfaction with anaesthtic measured within 4 hours of waking from the anaesthetic Y/N
Whether participant would have same intravenous agent again Y/N within 4 hours of waking from the anaesthetic

5 point Likert scale score of pain on injection of propofol measured in the recovery room or within 4 hours of waking from the anaesthetic. 0= Perfectly comfortable;1= minimal discomfort;2= some pain during injection;3= Moderate pain; 4=Severe pain

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Adults presenting for intravenous induction of anaesthesia with propofol.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Propofol allergy; soya bean /egg allergy; severe intellectual handicap; deafness; needing an english interpreter.

trial_design.designfeatures: Subjects, Observer, Data analysis will be blinded

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: Children, Youth and Women's Health Service(CYWHS)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study plans to investigate whether statements made during intravenous induction of anaesthesia with propofol affect the perception of pain on injection.

contact.name: Dr A.M. Cyna
contact.address: Department of Women's Anaesthesia Women's and Children's Hospital 72 King William Road Adelaide SA 5006
